Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Sussman was the best professor I had this semester. He's smart, nice, and expects a lot of you. The class is eminently practical (for those who want a career in energy policy) and it's fun (which is no easy feat given the material). The best!
3 - While the workload was heavy for 2 credits, it was very appropriate for anyone wanting to learn a lot about the Clean Power Plan.

This course provided a solid and rigorous grounding in the EPA's clean power plan (CPP). Prof Sussman did a good job of making the material available to students with different levels of background knowledge. The assignment to write a memo for state implementation was very useful - it forced me to look at the CPP in a new light and really understand the challenges of implementation for certain states.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The way Sussman ran his class--this was the only FES course I took this semester that successfully ran itself as a discussion seminar. Very impressive!
Class discussions that were teed up by Professor Sussman.

Getting an in depth understanding about a key piece of the U.S.'s current plan to address climate change. Professor Sussman's many years of experience with the subject matter and contacts with key players.

The assignments were useful. The financing classes with guests from CGC were especially useful. I think the classes on the CPP itself were much more useful that the some of the initial background classes, but Prof Sussman was very accommodating - accelerating launch into main material in response to students' requests.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Nothing needed improving.
Sometimes the background lectures went a bit long and would've liked to have more time for discussions.
-Professor Sussman tried to make up for his difficulty hearing by moving closer to speakers, but maybe having a microphone system for everyone or some other technology could have helped.
Class discussion covered a lot of useful ground, but sometimes derailed drilling down into one facet of the material and then missing the opportunity to cover other material as time ran short.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am studying climate and energy policy in the U.S. and so learning about the Clean Power Plan in depth will be extremely useful for my career after FES.
I am trying to better understand current and potential climate change solutions and their impacts, so learning how the EPA is attempting to limit carbon emissions from power plants was very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn about the Clean Power Plan and hear different perspectives from Professor Sussman and my classmates.
See question 17.
I wanted to better understand the CPP and the potential legal issues entangled with it. I think this course met those needs well.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: This course exceeded my expectations.
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The group projects in this course were uniquely helpful. Not only did we learn a lot from our group work, but we learned a lot from the other groups' presentations. Well done!

I would've liked to see my group members volunteer to help with the researching and writing for the more technical aspects for our final group paper. I was mainly responsible for this and it would've been helpful to be able to talk to my group members more about it.
I learned a lot from my group members, but it was frustrating at times because one member was not as invested as the rest.
Very helpful for working through the technical material - good to talk it out with others. It also allowed us to cover a lot more ground.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it this class is the best!

If you want to learn about U.S. climate policy and the Clean Power Plan, which will most likely be around for years to come, then this is a great technically-focused course that dives into the details.
Professor Sussman is a great resource on the Clean Power Plan, but sometimes his monotone lectures could make it hard to stay engaged.
Take it if you want to understand the Clean Power Plan and how it might influence domestic climate and energy policy in the coming years.
